poem:
**Flood at Dawn**

Grey whispers in the night,  
a brook's careless song—  
rain's relentless fingers  
twist the hour's wrong.  
Fields drown in silence;  
terrors an unwelcome guest,  
echoes of helplessness  
in the heart's damp breast.  
Yet somewhere, beneath  
mud's heavy veils,  
a defiant seed  
awaits the sun's tales.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Everything is destroyed, nothing could be saved:’ anger and despair in communities devastated by North West floods At about 3.15am on New Year’s Day, Caroline McClymont looked out of her bedroom window at the Sankey brook over the road. It looked a bit fuller than usual – to be expected, given the rain. “But there was nothing out of the ordinary,” McClymont said. “There was no indication it was going to flood.” Within an hour,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
